bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 10, 1876

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence about a rumor of her impending marriage. He plans a visit to see her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 10, 1876
div1.p:
Why did
you not write to me, last
Friday, so that I could have
a sweet little letter from your
darling little self, at the be-
ginning of the week? Now
my precious, it is really
cruel to keep me waiting
from morning till night, ex-
pecting to hear from you,
and then not receive a word-
Don't you know that such
disappointment will ruin
your little boy's health and
cause him to pine away
to such an extent that you
will not recognize him
when you next see him? Think
how devotedly he loves you,
and see if you can find it
in your heart to keep him
waiting again in vain- I
would think that you were
sick did I not know that, if
such were the case, you would
not keep me ignorant, one
hour. Perhaps, you are collec-
ting all the information you
can, in order to answer my
questions about Murfreesboro.
Now what do you suppose
I have heard? Oh! Lo! I,
away here at Willets Point!
Promise not to tell anybody,
& I'll divulge - well, here it is-
I heard that Miss Emilie B.
Lawrence was to be married
very soon- within a few
weeks- A certain person, now
residing in your town, wrote
to a certain other person,
living elsewhere, that there
could be no doubt of the
matter- That Miss E.B.L. had
not been to church, for several
sundays, & hence it must be
very plain, in fact simply ir-
resistible evidence that her
marriage was not far distant.
What do you think of that?
Now, if you will be a very
good, little girl, & promise
to write to me punctually,
and write long letters, &
not require me to write long
ones, in return, I'll tell you
the name of the person who
said so. With such easy
terms, you can't refuse.
Before I forget it, tell me
please, the date of the February
concerts at the Methodist
College. I have been thinking
that it would be a good time
for me to make my visit, un-
less it occurs too late in
the months - When I think of
the near approach of the time when
I shall see my own darling,
little girl, it makes my heart to
leap with joy- Bless, your darling
heart,! I would that the day
had arrived when I could
claim you as my own, &
have you with me always.
I have many, many things to talk
over with you, for you know
that I value your opinion very
highly, & there are subjects of in-
terest to you & me, concerning
which I desire your advice.
div1.closer:
Excuse the brevity of my letter,
and believe me, darling, always
your fond & devoted Walter.
